_header: Pass forth thou pilgrim and bridle well thy beast
_description: ‘Balade moral of gode counseyle’ (ascribed in one MS to Gower) — five stanzas rhyme royal

BodAsh59.Transcription:
PAsse forþe þou pilgryme and bridel wele þy beesteLoke
                    not ageine for thing þat may betydeThenke what þou wilt but speke
                    ay with þe leesteAvyse þee weele who stondeþe þee
                    besyde……Remembre eke þat what man doþe
                    amisseþou haste or arte or may besuche as he is
BodAsh59.Attributed Title: Balade moral of gode counseyle made by Gower (f. 17v)
BodAsh59.Editions:
Meyer,  Paul. 
             John Gowers Beziehungen zu Chaucer und König Richard II.
         Bonn: Georgi, 1889: 72.
Macaulay,  George Campbell,
                        ed.  
             English Works of John Gower.
             2 vols. 
             EETS
         e.s. 81, 82 (1900, 1901); repr. 1978: clxxiii.

BodRawC86.First Lines:
Passe forthe þu pilgryme and brydell wele þi besteloke
                    not a gayne for þynge þat may be tyde…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…But loke be hynde & war þe fram herstongeThow shalt
                    haue hurt yf þu play with her lond longe
BodRawC86.Editions:
Meyer,  Paul. 
             John Gowers Beziehungen zu Chaucer und König Richard II.
         Bonn: Georgi, 1889: 72.

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Passe forthe pilgryme and bridle well thy beasteloke not agayne for
                    thyngs þat may betyde…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…thynke well all weye that what man doth amyssethow hast or
                    art or may be as he is
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
A leson to kepe well þe tonge owt of Mstr hanlays booke (heading, f.
                        6v); Explicit to kepe thy tonge well per Magistrum benedictum
                    burgh (below last line, f. 7); both by scribe (John Stow)
BLAdd29729.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “über Benedict Burghs Leben und Werke.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         101 (1898): 53-5: 50-1.
